Class Fish

  • java.lang.Object
    • Fish

  • public class Fish
extends java.lang.Object
    You are given two non-empty zero-indexed arrays A and B consisting of N integers. Arrays A and B represent N voracious fish in a river, ordered downstream along the flow of the river. The fish are numbered from 0 to N − 1. If P and Q are two fish and P < Q, then fish P is initially upstream of fish Q. Initially, each fish has a unique position. Fish number P is represented by A[P] and B[P]. Array A contains the sizes of the fish. All its elements are unique. Array B contains the directions of the fish. It contains only 0s and/or 1s, where: 0 represents a fish flowing upstream, 1 represents a fish flowing downstream. If two fish move in opposite directions and there are no other (living) fish between them, they will eventually meet each other. Then only one fish can stay alive − the larger fish eats the smaller one. More precisely, we say that two fish P and Q meet each other when P < Q, B[P] = 1 and B[Q] = 0, and there are no living fish between them. After they meet: If A[P] > A[Q] then P eats Q, and P will still be flowing downstream, If A[Q] > A[P] then Q eats P, and Q will still be flowing upstream. We assume that all the fish are flowing at the same speed. That is, fish moving in the same direction never meet. The goal is to calculate the number of fish that will stay alive.
    Version:
    Oct 19, 2015
    Author:
    Tyler Hagerty

      given two non-empty zero-indexed arrays A and B consisting of N integers, returns the number of fish that will stay alive according to the rules & problem description above.

      • solution

        public static int solution(int[] A,
                           int[] B)
        given two non-empty zero-indexed arrays A and B consisting of N integers, returns the number of fish that will stay alive according to the rules & problem description above.
        Parameters:
        A - The array of integers representing the fish at the ith position's size
        B - The array of integers representing the fish's direction; 0 for upstream, 1 for downstream Upwards = moving towards the zero index, downwards = the opposite direction
        Returns:
        The number of surviving fish that swim on past all other fish moving in the opposite direction without being eaten, an integer
